title-group.article-title: The numerical modeling of abrasion resistance in casting aluminum–silicon alloy matrix composites

article-meta.aff: Materials and Energy Research Center (MERC), Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mohammad Reza Rahimipour, Materials and Energy Research Center (MERC), Tehran, Iran Email: m-rahimi@merc.ac.ir

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The wear properties of particulate-reinforced metal matrix has been generally found to be a function of the applied load as well as the reinforcement volume fraction, particle size, and the shape and nature of the reinforcing phase. In the present study, aluminum matrix composites reinforced with boron carbide particles have been fabricated and then abrasive wear rate of unreinforced alloy and composites are studied using pin-on-disc machine. Based on experimental results, composites exhibit better wear resistance compared to unreinforced alloy. The abrasion resistance of the composites increased with increasing the volume fraction. At a constant volume fraction of B4C reinforcement, the abrasion resistance increased with an increase in the reinforcement size within the range studied. Artificial neural network (ANN) models with various training algorithms were performed in order to find the error by comparing the output value of the network with the target value and then minimizing the difference (error) by modifying the weights. The results of algorithm analyses revealed that the best performance was given by Levenberg–Marquardt learning.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the last decades, aluminum matrix composites (AMCs) have been transformed from a topic of scientific and intellectual interest to a material of broad technological and commercial significance. Important AMC applications in the ground transportation (auto and rail), thermal management, aerospace, industrial, recreational, and infrastructure industries have been enabled by functional properties that include high structural efficiency, excellent wear resistance, and attractive thermal and electrical characteristics.1,2 Stir casting is one of the most conventional practices of preparation of aluminum–silicon (Al–Si) alloy-based composites, which involves the addition of particles such as boron carbide (B4C) to the liquid Al by a mechanical stirrer. There are excellent reviews on the tribology of AMCs. The applied load, reinforcement volume fraction, particle size, and the shape, nature of the reinforcing phase, and matrix structure influence the wear behavior of metal matrix composites (MMCs).3–13

An artificial neural network (ANN) is a ‘black box’ to which inputs are supplied and it gives outputs after some computational processing. The structure or architecture of ANNs is usually specified by the number of the layers in the ANN model and the number of the neurons in each layer. Various training algorithms are used in neural network applications. It is hardly difficult to predict which of these learning will be the fastest one for any problem. Generally, it depends on some factors: the structure of the networks, in other words, the number of hidden layers, weights, and biases in the network; aimed error at the learning; and application area, for instance, pattern recognition, classification, or function approximation problem. However, the data structure and uniformity of the training set are also important things that affect the system accuracy and performance. Some of the famous train algorithms are as follows:14–27
Random order incremental training with learning functions.
Resilient back propagation (Rprop).
gradient descent back propagation,
Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (BFGS) quasi-Newton back propagation.
Bayesian regularization: It is a network-training function that updates the weight and bias values according to Levenberg-Marquardt (LM) optimization.

In this study, the performance of various training algorithms to predict wear properties of Al–B4C composites is investigated. The finite element method (FEM) was used for discretization which is implemented to calculate the transient temperature, cooling rate, and temperature gradient. At the start of training, the network creates a set of random weights between the neurons in the successive layers and computes the outputs. The calculated outputs are compared with the target values and the differences are the errors. According to the magnitude of the error, each weight is adjusted so as to reduce the total error. Then the calculation is performed once again using the adjusted weights in order to get a new set of outputs. These in turn are compared with the targets, and the weights are adjusted again. This process is repeated until an acceptable criterion is reached. For experiments in this article, the total error (i.e., error based on the mean square error [MSE]) between the network output and target was used as a criterion for terminating the training session. After satisfactory training, the neural network models were used for further simulations and predictions of tribological properties.

sec.title: Experimental procedure
sec.p: The B4C particles with average particle sizes of 1, 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 µm and volume fractions of 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10, 12.5, and 15 vol.% were used as the reinforcements, while commercial cast A356 Al alloy (A356) was utilized as the matrix material.

A graphite crucible for holding the materials is placed inside the experimental setup. There is a nitrogen supply to the crucible. A graphite stirrer mounted on a shaft is connected to a digital DC motor to stir the slurry. The melt-particle slurry was stirred for 15 min at approximately 600 rev./min speed. Magnesium and strontium were added to Al–Si alloys to improve the wettability between Al matrix and reinforcing particles and modification of eutectic Si particles, respectively.

Composite slurry was step cast into the CO2-sand mold. Figure 1 shows the scale drawing for step casting. The casting was gated from the side of the riser. It was then sectioned and samples were extracted from Steps 1–5. The density of composites was measured using the liquid displacement technique following the Archimedes principle. The amount of porosity in the cast alloy and the composites was determined by comparing the measured density with that of their theoretical density using rule-of-mixtures. Figure 1.
Scale drawing for step casting.
The microstructures of the produced ingots were examined using an optical microscope to determine the distribution of the B4C particles and presence of porosity.
Specimens for the wear tests were solution-treated at 540°C for 4 h, quenched into warm water (40°C), and then peak-aged to T6 condition (155°C for 9 h).

Dry sliding wear tests were performed using a pin-on-disc-type wear apparatus. The slider disc was case-hardened steel with 63 Hardness Rockwell C (HRC) to a depth of 3 mm. Composites were made into pins 6 mm in diameter and 25 mm in height. The pins were put in contact with the slider. Both surfaces were polished to 0.5 pm and ultrasonically cleaned prior to testing. The tests were carried for different sliding distances under the normal loads of 10 and 20 N. The weight losses were calculated from the differences in weight of the specimens measured before and after the tests to the nearest 0.1 mg using an analytical balance. A separate specimen was used to measure the weight loss for each sliding distance. The wear test was interrupted at regular intervals and the incremental weight loss of the sample was recorded. After each increment and before weighing, the disk and the pin were cleaned in an ultrasonic bath with acetone and hot-wind dried below 100°C. Results from the specimens with wear track geometries that were not compatible with the specification of American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) standard G99-95 were discarded. All tests were performed at room temperature (21°C, relative humidity 55%).

sec.title: Modeling
sec.p: In order to simulate the solidification of composites, the numerical model is applied. In this research, wear properties are considered to be related to the cooling rate, temperature gradient, volume percentage of B4C (0, 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10, 12.5, and 15), average particle size of B4C (1, 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 µm), applied load (10 and 20 N), and sliding distance (0, 200, 400, 600, 800, 1000, and 1200 m). The mathematical formulation of this solidification problem is given by:28 (1)ρC∂T(x,y,z,t)∂t=K∇2T(x,y,z,t)+ρLδfsδt where ρ is the density (kg/m3), C is the specific heat (J/kg K), T is the temperature (K), t is the time (s), K is the thermal conductivity (W/m K), L is the latent heat (J/kg), and fs is the local solid fraction. The fraction of solid in the mushy zone is estimated by the Scheil equation, which assumes perfect mixing in the liquid and no solid diffusion. With the liquidus and solidus having constant slopes, fs is then expressed as:28 (2)fS=1-(Tf-TTf-Tliq)1/(k0-1), where Tf is the melting temperature (K), Tliq is the liquidus temperature (K), and k0 is the partition coefficient. Then:29 (3)δfsδt=1(k0-1)(Tf-Tlig)(Tf-TTf-Tlig)(2-k0)/(k0-1)δTδt

The latent heat released during solidification of the remaining liquid of eutectic composition was taken into account by a device, which considers a temperature accumulation factor: (4)ρC'∂T(x,y,z,t)∂t=K∇2T(x,y,z,t)+ρLδfsδt where C′ can be considered as a pseudo-specific heat given by:29 (5)C'=CM-LδfsδT (6)CM=(1-fs)Kl+fsCS, where the subscripts l, s, and M refer to liquid, solid, and mushy, respectively.
The other properties such as thermal conductivity and density in the mushy zone are described similarly as the specific heat: (7)KM=(1-fs)Kl+fsKS (8)ρM=(1-fs)ρl+fsρS.
The FEM was used for discretization. Based on the above transient temperature model, the FEM method is used to calculate the transient temperature, cooling rate (R), and temperature gradient (G).

In the analysis of performance of various training algorithms, the same prepared learning and test set were used in the training processes of each learning algorithm. The performance analysis was done from the viewpoint of training duration, error minimization, and prediction achievement. The neural network predictions were directly compared with the experimental obtained data to evaluate the learning performance. The MSE, which is a statistical and scientific error computation method, was used to analyze the error.17–20

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
The optical micrographs indicate the presence of α-Als and distributed B4C particles in A356/B4C composite alloys (Figure 2). It is noted that B4C particles play roles as heterogeneous nucleation sites for eutectic Si and a physical barrier for growing of eutectic Si during solidification. It is also observed that the dendrite branches were left as particle-free regions in the material.30,31 Figure 2.
Typical optical micrograph of the composite with 5 vol.% boron carbide (B4C; 30 µm).

Strontium was used in order to modify the Si particle from acicular to fine fibrous. Figure 3 shows the segregation of strontium on the particle/matrix interface due to elemental portioning and formation of Al–Si–Sr intermetallic compound in interdendritic regions which are responsible for consuming a large amount of free strontium in the matrix.32,33 It is generally believed that incorporation of hard ceramic particles to monolithic alloys contributes in improving the wear resistance of Al to a great extent.32,34 The reported results suggest that the wear resistance of Al–B4C composite increases by the addition of strontium in all applied loads. Lee et al.35 showed that eutectic Si particles are more brittle than ceramic particulates added as reinforcement. In this case, the acicular shape of unmodified Si particles indicates that lower stress is needed for local fracture of Si particles in comparison with B4C-reinforcing particles. Therefore, the refinement of Si particles could decrease the stress concentration effects on Si particles and increase the wear properties. Figure 3.
Typical scanning electron microscope (SEM) micrographs of the composites with (a) 2.5 vol.% boron carbide (B4C; 40 µm) and (b) 7.5 vol.% B4C (50 µm).

Earlier studies show that ceramic particles act as load-bearing elements. Figure 4 summarized the effect of volume percentage, particle size, and applied load on the weight loss of the composites. The weight losses of the composites are clearly less than that of unreinforced alloy and decrease with increasing B4C volume percentage. This is in agreement with the previously reported results.7,10,11 Figure 4.
Typical variations of wear loss as a function of sliding distance for different average sizes of the boron carbide (B4C) particles: (a) 1 µm under 10 N, (b) 30 µm under 10 N, (c) 50 µm under 10 N, (d) 1 µm under 20 N, (e) 30 µm under 20 N, and (f) 50 µm under 20 N.

The B4C particles protect the matrix and Si phase from the applied load. The brittle nature of B4C causes it to get fragmented and redistributed on the surface resulting in relief of the shear strains built up in the subsurface.

The highest applied load which can be supported by the B4C particles is known as the transient load. Figure 4 shows that weight losses of the composites and unreinforced alloy increase with increasing the applied load. It was reported in the previous research that the particles act as load-bearing components when the nominal load is lower than the transient load. It is also reported that the larger particles help to carry a greater portion of the applied load which means that the critical load required for causing the fracture of particles increases with increasing size of the particles. Thus, the presence of particles in the matrix leads to reduction of the wear of the composite. According to Figure 4, mild and severe wear can be indentified in wear rates of the unreinforced and reinforced alloys.

A prerequisite for the mild wear is that the B4C particles should remain intact during wear in order to support the applied load and act as effective abrasive elements. The severe wear occurs when the stresses induced by the applied load exceed the fracture strength of carbide particles. This causes the fracture of particles and losing their effectiveness as load-bearing components. The shear strains are then transmitted to the matrix alloy and wear proceeds by a subsurface delamination process. In this case, the lower ductility of Al–B4C composites appears to control the wear rates rather than the hardness of particles, resulting in wear rates almost similar to those observed in Al–Si alloys without B4C reinforcement.

In order to understand the changes that occur on the sliding surface of the samples during wear, EDS analyses of the debris were carried out. Figure 5(a)–(c) shows the EDS spectra on worn surface of Al–7% Si and Al−7% Si−7.5% B4C tested at the loads of 10 and 20 N. These results indicate that the worn surfaces of the composites were covered by layers containing iron (Fe) from the counterface material confirming the presence of mechanical mixed layer. Figure 5.
The energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) analysis of the composite wear debris: (a) unreinforced A356 alloy (20 N), (b) A356-7.5% boron carbide (B4C) particles (20 µm, 10 N), and (c) A356–7.5% B4C particles (20 µm, 20 N).

Figure 6(a) and (b) shows the Fe content variation on the worn surface with B4C content at different applied loads and B4C particle sizes. It is observed that the debris of the composites with low wear rate is associated with the formation of more Fe-rich layers on the contact surfaces. During sliding wear, Fe, and possibly other alloying elements, from the steel counterface are transferred to the surface of the composites. The Fe-rich transfer layers help the B4C particles to remain unbroken during wear and act as load-bearing elements. It is also reported that Fe is oxidized during this process and oxide layers, in particular Fe203 layers generated during wear, act as solid lubricants and help to reduce the wear rates.36–38 Figure 6.
The iron (Fe) content on the worn surface: (a) effect of applied load and (b) effect of particle size.

The results of SEM examination of the worn surfaces of the composites and the matrix alloy are shown in Figure 7. The worn surfaces of all specimens were covered with grooves parallel to the sliding direction and some plastic deformations. These grooves are typical features associated with abrasive wear, in which hard asperities on the steel counterface or hard particles between the pin and disc plough or cut into the pin causing wear by the removal of the material. Plastic deformation, material smearing, cavities, and craters imply adhesive wear. Figure 7(a) revealed the excessive plastic ploughing and cutting in the unreinforced Al alloy. Figure 7(b) and (c) shows that the rough and smooth regions are distinguished on the worn surface of the composites similar to the unreinforced alloy. Less portion of adhesive mechanism, smoother worn surface, and smaller depth of deformation that are observed in composites in relative to unreinforced alloy can all be attributed to the presence of hard reinforcement. Figure 7.
SEM micrographs of worn surfaces: (a) unreinforced A356 (20 N), (b) 10% boron carbide (B4C) particles (40 µm, 10 N), and (c) 5% B4C particles (50 µm, 20 N).

The Al–Si matrix composites have a large fraction of primary α-Al in their microstructure which can be grain-refined leading to the formation of fine dendritic structure. Fine grain structure leads to several benefits such as improved mechanical properties, improved feeding during solidification, reduced and more evenly distributed shrinkage porosity, better dispersion of the second phase, and improved surface finish. The results of this study show that wear of the composites is also influenced by the microstructure of the matrix. It is evident that the increase in cooling rate not only results in a decrease in dendrite arm spacing (DAS) but also lowers the eutectic Si particle size. It has been suggested that the grain refinement improves wear resistance and the load-bearing capacity during dry sliding of cast Al–7% Si alloy.39 Similarly, in the present investigation, the increase in cooling rate resulted in a combined effect of grain refinement, modification, and dispersion strengthening leading to an improvement in wear resistance of composites.

The ANN technique is a powerful statistical methodology used to recognize the correlations between the parameters of a given problem and its responses. The input and output data set of the model are illustrated schematically in Figure 8 and the MSE values for training data are given for each training algorithm in Figure 9. The obtained error values for different number of neurons in the hidden layers and number of hidden layers were analyzed and given graphically. This figure also gives information about the accuracy of five famous training algorithms depending on the number of neurons in the hidden layers and number of hidden layers. It is evident from this figure; the least error value was obtained by using LM training algorithm with two hidden layers and four neurons. The BFGS quasi-Newton back propagation with one hidden layer and eight neurons in the hidden layer follows LM algorithm, and thirdly, gradient descent back propagation including two hidden layers and eight neurons in the hidden layers has clearly much error than the previous two ones. The most errors were obtained from the Rprop and Random order incremental training with learning functions. The LM training algorithm was found to be the fastest training algorithm; however, it requires more memory with the same error convergence bound compared to training methods.19 The MSE is a good criterion to have information about learning performance. The iterations were continued until it is decided that the minimum MSE error is obtained. As can be seen, there is remarkable agreement between the experimental and predicted values with this MSE, which implies that the ANN model can be used to predict the wear properties. Figure 10(a), (b), (c), and (d) shows the cooling rate, DAS, the size of the eutectic Si, and weight loss distributions of the composites, respectively. Figure 8.
Schematic representation of the neural network architecture. Figure 9.
Evaluation of the training performance of the networks for different training algorithms according to mean square error (MSE) values with, one hidden layer (a), two hidden layers (b), three hidden layers (c), and four hidden layers (d). Figure 10.
Distribution: (a) the cooling rate, (b) dendrite arm spacing (DAS), (c) the size of the eutectic silicon (Si), and (d) weight loss.

In addition, success of the algorithms depends on the user-dependent parameters, learning rate and momentum constant. Faster algorithms such as quasi-Newton and LM use standard numerical optimization techniques. These algorithms eliminate some of the above mentioned disadvantages. The LM method is in fact an approximation of the Newton’s method.19 The algorithm uses the second-order derivatives of the cost function so that a better convergence behavior can be obtained. In the ordinary gradient descent search, only the first-order derivatives are evaluated and the parameter change information contains solely the direction along which the cost is minimized, whereas the LM technique extracts a biter parameter change vector.

Figure 11 shows the efficacy of the optimization scheme by comparing the ANN results with the experimental values. There is a convincing agreement between experimental values and predicted values for DAS and weight loss of A356−B4C composites for LM training algorithm. Figure 11.
Comparison between the experimental and predicted values: dendrite arm spacing (DAS) (a) and wear loss (b).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The Al−B4C composites have been processed using stir casting. It is concluded that the abrasion resistance of the composites increased with increasing the volume fraction and decreasing the size of B4C particles within the range studied. The wear rate results of the unreinforced and reinforced alloys show severe and mild wear rate regimes. The transition from severe to mild wear is attributed to the extent of Fe deposition which was more significant for composites with low wear rate in comparison to the ones with high wear rate. There appears to be a correlation between the matrix microstructure and the wear. It is also concluded that LM method with four neurons in two hidden layers gives the best prediction of wear properties in A356−B4C composites.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Conflict of interests
sec.p: None declared.
